body: @ZihengJiang looks like its related to quantize op
you can workaround it temporarily by deleting quantize/dequantize ops under contrib

@piiswrong - Yes, this is also what we decided with @szha. We can add examples on the main page that he is working on currently. 

The docstrings for things like unpack_weights definitely need some context and examples inside would be too long. So I tried to take a midway solution with a small description for now.
I've realized that extending to 5D support was almost trivial, so i've added that as well

it looks like the problem can be solved by setting 

ptr = new storage::NaiveStorageManager<storage::GPUDeviceStorage>();

instead of GPUPooledStorageManager in storage.cc

Can this be made as an option to be configured at runtime? It really is a bad practice to allocate all available GRAM and never release it. Another option is to add a public method that would allow all allocated memory to be released.

should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6131. Also, I suggest adding this build combination into CI

tested on both linux and mac, should be ok to merge. but not all notebooks converted from mxnet-notebooks are carefully examined. we need to either fix them after merged, or fix them first before merging, which means working on the `doc4` branch for several days.

one simple solution is that letting all workers compute the gradients, but on the server side only merge a part of workers, namely dropping the gradients arrived at the end, by changing

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/kvstore/kvstore_dist_server.h#L179

also, you can let a worker sleep a random time to simulate the stragglers before each data push

Thanks for the response! Does this method save computational resources during the gradient computation? It seems like even with this change, every machine will still be doing the same amount of gradient computation; in other words, gradient computation is not skipped via the skip_exec_node flag. Is this true or am I missing something?

Is there a way to actually skip computing gradients when a flag is set?

What we are trying to achieve is the following: if a worker is computing gradients for a 10-layer neural network (and suppose it just finished computing gradients for the third layer), then upon the setting the skip_exec_node flag, the worker skips computing gradients for layers 4-10. Is this possible to achieve?

@sxjscience The existing module API can actually do low level forward backward easily, as a demo shown [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/module/mnist_mlp.py#L45) for writing your own explicit training loop. But comparing to PyTorch's full interface, it is still a bit basic. I do think we have a lot to learn from PyTorch / Chainer API design by either extending module or have a new API.

You can create two modules, A for layer 1-3, B for layer 4-10. then a node can randomly to skip to call A.backward to reduce the cost. But you cannot skip B.backward because it is required for A.backward. 

http://mxnet.io/tutorials/python/module.html

But it's hard to skip a random layer until @piiswrong 's imperative training is done.

@sbodenstein

This is too long. Its as simple as a `pip install mxnet` for most users and that's the whole point. We shouldn't make it appear more complicated than it is.

We should keep the original one sentence instruction. You can put this in a trouble shooting page if necessary.

ok.
note that is is mostly for partial loading. 
if you are loading the exact same model you can module.load directly.
this is useful when you want to initialize your new (with more params) model from a pretrained model.

```
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Template configuration for compiling mxnet
#
#  If you want to change the configuration, please use the following
#  steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this
#  file so that any local changes will be ignored by git
#
#  $ cp make/config.mk .
#
#  Next modify the according entries, and then compile by
#
#  $ make
#
#  or build in parallel with 9 threads
#
#  $ make -j9
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------
# choice of compiler
#--------------------

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with options for MXNet developer
DEV = 1

# whether compile with debug
DEBUG = 1

# whether compiler with profiler
USE_PROFILER =

# the additional link flags you want to add
ADD_LDFLAGS = -L/lrz/sys/intel/studio2018_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/lib/intel64 -Wl,--start-group /lrz/sys/intel/studio2017_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/lib/intel64/libmkl_intel_lp64.a /lrz/sys/intel/studio2017_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/lib/intel64/libmkl_intel_thread.a /lrz/sys/intel/studio2017_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/lib/intel64/libmkl_core.a -Wl,--end-group -liomp5 -lpthread -lm


# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS = -I/lrz/sys/intel/studio2018_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/include -I/lrz/sys/intel/studio2017_u2/compilers_and_libraries_2017.2.174/linux/mkl/include/intel64/lp64 

#---------------------------------------------
# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU
#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile
USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag
# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CuDNN R4 library
USE_CUDNN = 1

# CUDA architecture setting: going with all of them.
# For CUDA < 7.0, comment the *_50 lines for compatibility.
CUDA_ARCH := -gencode arch=compute_31,code=sm_30 \
		-gencode arch=compute_36,code=sm_35 \
		-gencode arch=compute_51,code=sm_50 \
		-gencode arch=compute_51,code=compute_50

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)
USE_NVRTC = 1

# whether use opencv during compilation
# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use
# imbin iterator
USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization
USE_OPENMP = 1


# MKL ML Library for Intel CPU/Xeon Phi
# Please refer to MKL_README.md for details

# MKL ML Library folder, need to be root for /usr/local
# Change to User Home directory for standard user
# For USE_BLAS!=mkl only
MKLML_ROOT=/home/hpc/pr75ze/ru37wof2/local_software/

# whether use MKL2018 library
USE_MKL2018 = 1

# whether use MKL2018 experimental feature for high performance
# Prerequisite USE_MKL2018=1
USE_MKL2018_EXPERIMENTAL = 0

# whether use NNPACK library
USE_NNPACK = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use
# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas
# in default use atlas for linux while apple for osx
UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = apple
else
USE_BLAS = mkl
endif

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path
# to environment variable
USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

# If use MKL only for BLAS, choose static link automatically to allow python wrapper
ifeq ($(USE_MKL2018), 0)
ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
USE_STATIC_MKL = 2
endif
else
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
endif

#----------------------------
# Settings for power and arm arch
#----------------------------
ARCH := $(shell uname -a)
ifneq (,$(filter $(ARCH), armv7l armv7l powerpc64le ppc64le aarch64))
	USE_SSE=1
else
	USE_SSE=2
endif

#----------------------------
# distributed computing
#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable multi-machine supporting
USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is
# required
USE_HDFS = 1

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=2
LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd65/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S4 directly. If yes, then
# libcurl5-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by
# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl5-openssl-dev
USE_S4 = 0

#----------------------------
# additional operators
#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't want to put in src/operators
EXTRA_OPERATORS =

#----------------------------
# other features
#----------------------------

# Create C++ interface package
USE_CPP_PACKAGE = 1

#----------------------------
# plugins
#----------------------------

# whether to use caffe integration. This requires installing caffe.
# You also need to add CAFFE_PATH/build/lib to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
# CAFFE_PATH = $(HOME)/caffe
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/caffe/caffe.mk

# whether to use torch integration. This requires installing torch.
# You also need to add TORCH_PATH/install/lib to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
# TORCH_PATH = $(HOME)/torch
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/torch/torch.mk

# WARPCTC_PATH = $(HOME)/warp-ctc
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/warpctc/warpctc.mk

# whether to use sframe integration. This requires build sframe
# git@github.com:dato-code/SFrame.git
# SFRAME_PATH = $(HOME)/SFrame
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/sframe/plugin.mk
```

@Mrugankakarte Can you share the data?

Yeah sure. I'm solving [House prices: Advanced regression techniques](https://www.kaggle.com/c/house-prices-advanced-regression-techniques) problem from kaggle. 
I have transformed the data. All the transformed and original data files with scripts are present [here](https://github.com/Mrugankakarte/Regression/tree/master/Data).

When I use the following code while creating the network ; it gives the prediction correctly 
```
>data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")  
>fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, name="fc1", num_hidden=1)  
>linear_reg_output <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
```
Above code means that it is simple regression where input and output nodes are connected to each other directly, right?
When I use the multi-layer network I get same predictions for each predictor as mentioned earlier

```
>data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
>fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, name="fc1", num_hidden=300)
>act1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, name="sigm1", act_type="sigmoid")
>fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act1, name="fc2", num_hidden=300)
>act2 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc2, name="sigm2", act_type="sigmoid")
>c3 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act2, name="fc3", num_hidden=300)
>act3 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc3, name="sigm3", act_type="sigmoid")
>fc4 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act3, name="fc4", num_hidden=1)
>linear_reg_output <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc4)
```

Thanks,

Here is a proposal of a Lotus Logo for Apache MXNet: Design Tenets used for the Lotus Logo for Apache MXNet: 1) The Logo is colorful. Here, the related colors are "mixed" to signify blend of: i) Symbolic and Imperative programming paradigms, ii) Synchronous and Asynchronous execution models, iii) CPU and GPU processor support, and iv) beautiful overlap of Computation and Communication in a Distributed System. 2) The Logo signifies some "deep" meaning. Here the fully "open" Lotus signifies rising and blooming above the complexity murk using the open-source, flexible and efficient Apache MXNet library to achieve an "enlightenment" of Deep Learning. 3) The Logo uses blue color for MXNet to match its web-site background color. 4) The Logo is distinguishable on a T-shirt from far or by a person not wearing his spectacles, making it easy to notice and remember the logo for the long-term. 5) The Logo is easy to draw on a white-board during MXNet training lectures. You can design many such alternative logos for free at https://www.logomaker.com and then pay $40 for a high-quality image file once the design is confirmed.

Yes it's doing initialization per key

What is the error you have now and can you post your symbol here?

For those parameters, it depends on how you compute them. What is you input image size? 
When you do predict you actually don't know the label shape. The default bucket key is used in training to allocate the memory. And bucket_key describes the shape your data. 

For example. if you want to predict a image of shape 300x30 with 100x1 as the input shape for lstm. You can have data_shape as 300x30 and bucket_key of 100 which tells how long the lstm is. The CTC is replaced with softmax in prediction.
is there any example for this?

I've moved this op to contrib (#6154).

Yes, I'll use a ubuntu machine to do the fix.

You should move `NDArray::WaitAll()` before x is evaluated, because after you call `exec->Forward()`, the value of its output will be cacluated asynchronously.

BTW, you can also use `auto c = a + b`, instead of calling `_Plus`.

The `bad` means for either compile error or performance issue.
It seems to be the same with the result I got under Windows.
The first bad commit may not bring the performance issue, but it (or the submodule) causes an compile error. And after this compile error disappeared, the performance became different.

@kevinthesun branch `doc4` has been merged, can you please create an another PR to merge into master directly?

1. What is your error when trying to load the model with my code?  Can you show me that log?
2. Are you able to load the parameters from model files?
3. Another thing I notice is that you are using old LSTM interface. Maybe you can try the new one which is more convinient.
4. As I mentioned more than once, the warpCTC is replaced with Softmax when you do testing. The good thing is that it has no parameters.

The bucket key of my code contains two parts. 1st is the warpCTC label length, 2nd is the lstm sequence length. Since you don't know the label length during testing, your bucket_key only represents the lstm sequence length. I suggest you to write another symbol for testing but shares same symbol names for those layers with parameters.
